content.text: Calculate the speed of the car at A
As the car travels from A to B, it loses \(40\mathrm{kJ}\) of energy due to friction
The car just manages to roll over the crest of the hill at B
Calculate the height \(h\)
At C, the car is slowed down by a shallow tank of water and the kinetic energy of is reduced to zero
Make **three** suggestions for what happens to this kinetic energy
Fig. 1.1 shows a car on a roller-coaster ride
mass of car \(= 600\mathrm{kg}\)
kinetic energy of car at point A \(= 160\mathrm{kJ}\)
On Fig. 2.1, draw the resultant force acting on the airliner. Explain your answer
The weight of the airliner is \(1.20 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N}\) and there is an aerodynamic lift force of \(1.39 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N}\) acting at \(30^{\circ}\) to the left of the vertical
By drawing a scale vector diagram, or otherwise, show that the resultant of these two forces is in the same direction as the resultant force you drew in **(a)**
The speed is constant as the airliner flies in this circular path
State and explain what is happening to the velocity
Fig. 2.1 is a head-on view of an airliner flying at constant speed in a circular horizon
The centre of the circle is to the left of the diagram
A particular thermometer is sensitive, linear and has a wide range
Draw a straight line from each characteristic of this thermometer to the appropriate feature
characteristic of thermometer feature of thermometer
reacts quickly to change of temperature
sensitive
large difference between highest and lowest measurable temperatures
linear same change of physical property for same change of temperature
fixed points at \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) and \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
wide range
large change of physical property for small change of temperature
In the space below, draw a diagram to show the structure of a thermocouple thermometer
Explain why a thermocouple thermometer is particularly well suited to mea
1. high temperatures,
2. very rapidly changing temperatures
A thermometer uses the value of a physical property to indicate the temperature
On Fig. 4.1, draw a possible new position for the lower face of the piston
Explain, in terms of the molecules of the gas and the molecules of the atmosphere, your answer to (a)(i)
Fig. 4.1 shows some gas contained in a cylinder by a heavy piston. The piston can up and down in the cylinder with negligible friction
There is a small increase in the pressure of the atmosphere above the piston
On Fig. 4.2, draw a possible new position for the lower face of the piston
Explain, in terms of the molecules of the gas and the molecules of the atmosphere, your answer to (b)(i)
The pressure of the atmosphere above the piston returns to its original value,
piston returns to its original position, as shown in Fig. 4.2
The gas, piston and cylinder are now heated to a much higher temperature
Suggest and explain a difference that the students will feel when holding the cups
The students discuss this experience with their teacher, who makes hot drink subject of an experiment
The same volume of hot water at the same temperature is placed in the single cup and in the double cup
The temperature of the water in each cup is recorded for 10 minutes
Fig. 5.3 shows the cooling curve for the water in the single cup
On Fig. 5.3, sketch and label a possible cooling curve for the water in the double cup
Explain why a cup of coffee cools more slowly when a lid is placed over the cup
Fig. 5.1 shows a thin plastic cup containing hot coffee, which an IGCSE Physics student from a machine
Fig. 5.2 shows how another student, who finds an empty second cup, has placed his identical cup of coffee inside this second cup
Fig. 5.1 Fig. 5.2
Calculate the average energy that the solar panels deliver to the water in one hour. Specific heat capacity of water \(= 4200 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)
The solar power incident on the roof during this heating period is \(170 \text{W} / \text{m}^2\). The solar panels have a total area of \(8.0 \text{m}^2\)
Calculate the solar energy incident on the panels in one hour
solar energy =   .........
Calculate the efficiency of the solar panels, stating the equation you use
Explain why solar energy is called _renewable_ energy
State one disadvantage of using solar energy
Solar panels are positioned on the roof of the house shown in Fig. 6.1. They use energy from the Sun to provide hot water in an environmentally friendly way
Cold water flows to the panels at \(15^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). During the day, the panels supply \(3.8\mathrm{kg}\) of hot water at \(65^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) every hour
On Fig. 7.1, draw a ray diagram to show the formation of this image
State why this type of image is called _virtual_
State the common name given to a convex lens used in this manner
A small object is placed \(3.0\mathrm{cm}\) from the centre of a convex lens of focal length \(6.0\) enlarged image is observed from the other side of the lens
A student rubs one side of an inflated balloon on her hair. This side of the becomes positively charged. Explain this
The charged side of the balloon is now brought close to a stream of water flowing from a pipe. The original position of the stream of water is shown in Fig. 8.1
On Fig. 8.1, write in the boxes to indicate how each side of the stream of water is electrically charged
Choose your answer in each case from: positive, negative or neutral
Fig. 8.1
